articles.headline: With Echoes of the ’30s, Trump Resurrects a Hard-Line Vision of ‘America First’
articles.snippet: In his inaugural address, President Trump appeared to herald the end of an American experiment to shape a world that would be eager to follow the United States’ lead.
articles.abstract: In his inaugural address, President Trump appeared to herald the end of an American experiment to shape a world that would be eager to follow the United States’ lead.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America, and the world, just found out what “America First” means.

articles.headline: In Inaugural Address, Trump Continues to Shun Establishment
articles.snippet: Uncompromising in tone and entirely in keeping with his insurgent campaign, President Trump dispensed with appeals to unity or attempts to build bridges to his opponents.
articles.abstract: Uncompromising in tone and entirely in keeping with his insurgent campaign, President Trump dispensed with appeals to unity or attempts to build bridges to his opponents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s Inaugural Address on Friday was a scalding repudiation of the Washington establishment. The question left hanging after this angry jeremiad: How will the new commander in chief be able to work with these people to govern the country?

articles.headline: Apple Adds to Qualcomm’s Troubles, Filing Lawsuit Over Rebates
articles.snippet: The chip maker’s technology is at heart of the smartphone revolution. But as the company’s influence grows, it is gaining unwanted antitrust attention.
articles.abstract: The chip maker’s technology is at heart of the smartphone revolution. But as the company’s influence grows, it is gaining unwanted antitrust attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — By mastering some tough computer chip technology and then pulling off an audacious business strategy based on selling its smartphone knowledge, Qualcomm has made billions of dollars and seized influence in the tech industry.

articles.headline: Many Left. Many Arrived. All Felt the Mood of a New Era.
articles.snippet: The atmosphere was unmistakable on Friday in Washington, where crowds gathered for President Trump’s inauguration, protests broke out and many residents simply skipped town.
articles.abstract: The atmosphere was unmistakable on Friday in Washington, where crowds gathered for President Trump’s inauguration, protests broke out and many residents simply skipped town.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The people gathered in nature’s gloom, squinting through a spitting rain, sizing up the man and his moment, in a city disinclined to welcome either.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Leaders Abroad, Joyful or Wary, Face Uncertainty of Trump Era
articles.snippet: Germany’s vice chancellor said the inaugural speech reflected a “drastic radicalization” of U.S. politics. But some world leaders embraced the new reality.
articles.abstract: Germany’s vice chancellor said the inaugural speech reflected a “drastic radicalization” of U.S. politics. But some world leaders embraced the new reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — There was dismay in Britain, applause in Russia and silence in Japan. French populists found hope, Mexican leaders expressed concern and Germany’s vice chancellor offered an allusion to his country’s dark past.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed, Steven Erlanger and Gerry Mullany

articles.headline: Quicken Loans, the New Mortgage Machine
articles.snippet: The mortgage lender, like the big banks before it, has come under regulatory scrutiny. Its feisty founder, Dan Gilbert, is unfazed.
articles.abstract: The mortgage lender, like the big banks before it, has come under regulatory scrutiny. Its feisty founder, Dan Gilbert, is unfazed.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A low buzz fills the air as an army of mortgage bankers, perched below floating canopies in a kaleidoscope of vivid pinks, blues, purples and greens, works the phones, promising borrowers easy financing and low rates for home loans.

articles.headline: At Student Loan Giant Navient, Troubled Past Was Prologue
articles.snippet: Allegations against student loan servicing company appear to follow a tainted pattern.
articles.abstract: Allegations against student loan servicing company appear to follow a tainted pattern.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deception. Cheating. Shortcuts.

articles.headline: Off Long Island, Wind Power Tests the Waters
articles.snippet: The nation’s biggest offshore wind project is up for approval, a test of how far states can pursue a clean-energy agenda in the Trump era.
articles.abstract: The nation’s biggest offshore wind project is up for approval, a test of how far states can pursue a clean-energy agenda in the Trump era.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a few years ago, the long-held dream of harnessing the strong, steady gusts off the Atlantic coast to make electricity seemed destined to remain just that. Proposals for offshore wind farms foundered on the shoals of high costs, regulatory hurdles and the fierce opposition of those who didn’t want giant industrial machinery puncturing the pristine ocean views.

articles.headline: San Francisco Asks: Where Have All the Children Gone?
articles.snippet: San Francisco has the lowest share of children of the country’s largest cities, a longstanding trend reinforced by a tech industry that skews young and single.
articles.abstract: San Francisco has the lowest share of children of the country’s largest cities, a longstanding trend reinforced by a tech industry that skews young and single.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a compact studio apartment on the fringes of the Castro district here a young couple live with their demanding 7-year-old, whom they dote on and take everywhere: a Scottish terrier named Olive.

articles.headline: With False Claims, Trump Attacks Media on Turnout and Intelligence Rift
articles.snippet: The president falsely accused journalists of inventing a rift between him and spy agencies and of deliberately understating the size of his inauguration crowd.
articles.abstract: The president falsely accused journalists of inventing a rift between him and spy agencies and of deliberately understating the size of his inauguration crowd.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump used his first full day in office on Saturday to unleash a remarkably bitter attack on the news media, falsely accusing journalists of both inventing a rift between him and intelligence agencies and deliberately understating the size of his inauguration crowd.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Defiant Voices Flood U.S. Cities as Women Rally for Rights
articles.snippet: In cities across the country and beyond, demonstrators protested the new president after an election that placed gender in the spotlight as never before.
articles.abstract: In cities across the country and beyond, demonstrators protested the new president after an election that placed gender in the spotlight as never before.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day after what many had assumed would be the inauguration of the first female president, hundreds of thousands of women flooded the streets of Washington, and many more marched in cities across the country, in defiant, jubilant rallies against the man who defeated her.
articles.byline: By Susan Chira and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: In a Rust Belt Town, the Women’s March Draws Shrugs and Cheers From Afar
articles.snippet: Women in Niles, Mich., 600 miles from Washington, disagreed on the need for the march and on the issues it focused on.
articles.abstract: Women in Niles, Mich., 600 miles from Washington, disagreed on the need for the march and on the issues it focused on.
articles.lead_paragraph: NILES, Mich. — When Jennifer Purucker, 31, was asked on Saturday morning what she thought of the Women’s March on Washington, she took a sip of coffee and shook her head. “Never heard of it,” she said.

articles.headline: Trump’s Vow to Repeal Health Law Revives Talk of High-Risk Pools
articles.snippet: Some lawmakers are pushing the idea of the pools, which in the past left many people with pre-existing conditions uncovered or with strict limits to health care.
articles.abstract: Some lawmakers are pushing the idea of the pools, which in the past left many people with pre-existing conditions uncovered or with strict limits to health care.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joanne Fitzgerald was getting divorced and was stressed out. When stomach pain kicked in, she saw a doctor to have it checked out.

articles.headline: Cubans Newly Blocked at U.S. Border Place Hopes in Trump
articles.snippet: The Obama administration ended special immigration privileges for Cubans after normalizing relations with Cuba. Now migrants arrive into a desperate limbo after an arduous journey.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration ended special immigration privileges for Cubans after normalizing relations with Cuba. Now migrants arrive into a desperate limbo after an arduous journey.
articles.lead_paragraph: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico — She spent weeks hiking through the Amazon, crossing a crocodile-filled river. She scaled border walls, escaped from immigration detention in Panama and slept in a church. Broke, hungry and exhausted, she found refuge with indigenous people in the jungle who took her in and fed her for a week.

articles.headline: After Success of Women’s March, a Question Remains: What’s Next?
articles.snippet: The challenge facing the organizers is figuring out how to channel the resolve and outrage of an organic protest into action that produces political change.
articles.abstract: The challenge facing the organizers is figuring out how to channel the resolve and outrage of an organic protest into action that produces political change.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a million people who turned out on Saturday for women’s marches in all 50 states have put down their placards, taken off their pink hats and ended their chants after what was an extraordinary display of dissent against the Trump presidency.
articles.byline: By Susan Chira and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Protests in Bangladesh Shake a Global Workshop for Apparel
articles.snippet: At least 14 activists and workers have been detained since labor unrest began last month in Bangladesh, source of much of the world’s clothing.
articles.abstract: At least 14 activists and workers have been detained since labor unrest began last month in Bangladesh, source of much of the world’s clothing.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first, the police knocked. Then they tried to kick the door down.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Maher Sattar

articles.headline: ‘Alternative Facts’ and the Costs of Trump-Branded Reality
articles.snippet: The falsehoods put forth by members of the Trump team imperil one of the country’s most valuable assets: its credibility.
articles.abstract: The falsehoods put forth by members of the Trump team imperil one of the country’s most valuable assets: its credibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump swore the presidential oath on Friday, he assumed responsibility not only for the levers of government but also for one of the United States’ most valuable assets, battered though it may be: its credibility.

articles.headline: To Secular Bangladeshis, Textbook Changes Are a Harbinger
articles.snippet: Revisions sought by Islamic scholars were barely noticeable to the public, but intellectuals see them as government accommodation of a larger shift toward radical Islam.
articles.abstract: Revisions sought by Islamic scholars were barely noticeable to the public, but intellectuals see them as government accommodation of a larger shift toward radical Islam.
articles.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Bangladesh’s Education Ministry was preparing to print the 2017 editions of its standard Bengali textbooks when a group of conservative Islamic religious scholars demanded the removal of 17 poems and stories they deemed “atheistic.”
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Julfikar Ali Manik

articles.headline: Rocky First Weekend for Trump Troubles Even His Top Aides
articles.snippet: To the extent that there was a plan to take advantage of the first days of his administration, when a president is usually at his maximum leverage, President Trump threw it aside.
articles.abstract: To the extent that there was a plan to take advantage of the first days of his administration, when a president is usually at his maximum leverage, President Trump threw it aside.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s first weekend in office unfolded much the way things often did during his campaign: with angry Twitter messages, a familiar obsession with slights and a series of meandering and at times untrue statements, all eventually giving way to attempts at damage control.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Galaxy Note 7 Fires Caused by Battery and Design Flaws, Samsung Says
articles.snippet: The company said it would form an outside advisory group and focus on quality assurance but offered little insight into the breakdowns that caused it to fail to identify the phone’s problems.
articles.abstract: The company said it would form an outside advisory group and focus on quality assurance but offered little insight into the breakdowns that caused it to fail to identify the phone’s problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Samsung, the South Korean conglomerate, blamed battery manufacturing problems and design flaws for the embarrassing and costly failure of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphone and apologized to its customers and suppliers.

articles.headline: Snapchat Discover Takes a Hard Line on Misleading and Explicit Images
articles.snippet: The social network has updated its guidelines for publishers, aiming to raise the bar on the quality of its news service — a move that may bode well for its planned I.P.O.
articles.abstract: The social network has updated its guidelines for publishers, aiming to raise the bar on the quality of its news service — a move that may bode well for its planned I.P.O.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On Snapchat last week, MTV published an article with the headline “Is this the thirstiest person on earth?” The article, which ran on Snapchat’s news service, Discover, appeared with a picture of a bikini-clad blond woman taking a selfie, even though the piece was about a fully clothed man.

articles.headline: Samsung Galaxy Note 7 Crisis Signals Problems at Korea Inc.
articles.snippet: A countrywide, top-down corporate culture stifles South Korean innovation and may have contributed to the company’s problems, critics say.
articles.abstract: A countrywide, top-down corporate culture stifles South Korean innovation and may have contributed to the company’s problems, critics say.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Before a world audience watching online, Samsung on Monday offered details and schematics showing how its Galaxy Note 7 smartphone went from cutting-edge technology to a costly, combustible failure.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: ‘Basic Economy’ Airline Service Squeezing Business Travelers
articles.snippet: When corporate travel managers insist on the least expensive flights, some employees must contribute their own money to make trips bearable.
articles.abstract: When corporate travel managers insist on the least expensive flights, some employees must contribute their own money to make trips bearable.
articles.lead_paragraph: As more airlines embrace “basic economy,” many business travelers are feeling the pinch.
